title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #219**, which asks whether there exist arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions of primes. The Green-Tao theorem (2008) proves the answer is YES.
mathContext: An arithmetic progression of primes has the form p, p+d, p+2d, ..., p+(k-1)d where all terms are prime. The question is whether such progressions exist for arbitrarily large k.

title: Arithmetic Progression
content: An **arithmetic progression** starting at a with common difference d and length k is the set {a, a+d, a+2d, ..., a+(k-1)d}. We represent this as a Finset using Finset.image.
mathContext: The formula a + i * d for i in range(k) generates all elements. This is the standard representation allowing easy computation and membership testing.

title: Prime Arithmetic Progression
content: A set is a **prime AP** if all its elements are prime AND it forms an arithmetic progression. This combines the structural requirement (AP form) with the number-theoretic requirement (primality).
mathContext: The predicate IsPrimeAP requires: (1) ∀ p ∈ S, p.Prime, and (2) ∃ a d k, S = arithmeticProg a d k with k ≥ 1, d > 0.

title: Example: {3, 5, 7}
content: The triple **{3, 5, 7}** is the simplest non-trivial example of a prime AP. It has first term 3, common difference 2, and length 3. All three are prime.
mathContext: This is the unique 3-term prime AP with difference 2. For larger differences, many 3-term APs exist (e.g., {5, 11, 17} with difference 6).

title: Example: {5, 11, 17, 23, 29}
content: The quintuple **{5, 11, 17, 23, 29}** is a 5-term prime AP with first term 5 and common difference 6. We verify each element is prime using norm_num.
mathContext: The common difference 6 = 2·3 is the smallest possible for a 5-term prime AP. Differences must be divisible by 2·3 = 6 for progressions of length ≥ 5.

title: The Main Question
content: **Erdős Problem #219**: For every k ≥ 1, does there exist a prime AP of length k? This asks whether we can find arbitrarily long prime APs, not just specific small examples.
mathContext: Formally: ∀ k ≥ 1, ∃ S : Finset ℕ, S.card = k ∧ IsPrimeAP S. This is a universal statement about existence for ALL k.

title: The Green-Tao Theorem
content: The **Green-Tao theorem** (2008) proves that primes contain arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. This is one of the most celebrated results in 21st century mathematics.
mathContext: The proof combines Szemerédi's theorem (APs in dense sets), ergodic theory, and a pseudorandomness argument to handle the sparseness of primes.

title: Explicit Formulation
content: An equivalent explicit formulation: for all k ≥ 1, there exist a, d with d > 0 such that a, a+d, a+2d, ..., a+(k-1)d are ALL prime.
mathContext: This makes the constructive content clearer: we need specific numbers a and d, not just abstract existence. Finding such a, d is computationally hard for large k.

title: Record: k = 23
content: The **longest known** arithmetic progression of primes has 23 terms, found by Pritchard, Moran, and others in 2019. The first term and common difference are astronomically large.
mathContext: The progression uses a = 56211383760397 and d involves the primorial 23# = 223092870. Finding k = 24 would require massive computational resources.

title: Open: Consecutive Prime APs
content: An **open problem**: Are there arbitrarily long APs of CONSECUTIVE primes? That is, can we find p₁ < p₂ < ... < pₖ forming an AP where each pᵢ is the immediate next prime after pᵢ₋₁?
mathContext: The longest known consecutive prime AP has 10 terms. This is much harder than arbitrary prime APs because we cannot skip primes.

title: Summary Theorem
content: The **summary** combines our main results: the Green-Tao theorem holds (axiomatized), {3, 5, 7} is verified as a prime AP, and {5, 11, 17, 23, 29} are all prime.
mathContext: This conjunction packages the key verified facts for export and reference.
